COUGARS' FIGHT SONG TURNS 50
Check out this amazing virtual performance the Clovis High School band and colorguard did of the Cougars' fight song to commemorate its 50th year.

The CHS Fight Song was written in September 1970 by then Clovis High band director Patrick Balakian.

The story goes that Balakian was good friends with Clovis Unified founding superintendent Dr. Floyd "Doc" Buchanan. One day, maybe during a Friday night football game as the former fight song "On Wisconsin" was played, Balakian went up to Doc and said," You know that Clovis is playing someone else's fight song?" Doc turned to Balakian and said, "So write one for us!" And he did.

Check out the tribute at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g1YAlHHHpFA&feature=youtu.be

#ClovisUnifiedStrong #Traditions #blueandgold

OFFICIAL OPENING CEREMONY!
Join us online Monday, Aug. 17, at 8:10 a.m. for the virtual presentation of the Jefferson Bell Ringing Ceremony at https://youtu.be/xhXiMecP4SM.

This 136-year tradition signifies the start of school for Clovis Unified's 43,000 students. The short ceremony will include comments from CUSD Superintendent Eimear O'Farrell.

This year’s bell ringers are Dianne Netz and Maral Kordoulanian, who work for Clovis Unified’s Campus Catering. They are representing the entire team of food service workers who are being honored for their tremendous efforts this spring and summer meeting the needs of our students and providing meals at various distribution sites.

The ceremony is held on the campus of Jefferson Elementary, where founding Clovis Unified Superintendent Floyd “Doc” Buchanan, Ed.D., originally had his office when the district unified in 1960. The bell is the original school bell that was housed in the one-room school in which Jefferson Elementary began its history.

Free, extra copies of the current edition of CUSD Today are available! This edition celebrates our Class of 2020, with excerpts from each school’s class speeches, lists of academic honor recipients and photo collages of each school’s graduation events.

If you see your favorite senior in this special publication and would like more copies to keep or send to relatives, we have a limited amount available.

WE LOVE A PARADE!
Several Clovis Unified schools have held (or will be holding) teacher parades through their school neighborhoods. Signs, streamers, chalk drawings and pom poms were used by teachers, students and parents to offer one another support and to let each other know how much they are missed.

Said Dry Creek Elementary Principal Aaron Cook - whose staff spent nearly three hours happily waving from their car windows last Friday - “We miss our kids! Our teachers were asking to do this. We didn’t have a chance to tell them goodbye before this [site closure] happened. This is a way we can reach out to see our students and tell them we love them in a safe, social distance environment.”

The love was definitely felt, and teachers from many schools said they were thrilled to see the smiling faces of their kids.
#BetterTogether
#InspiringExcellence
#InspiringEachOther

ONLINE KINDERGARTEN PRE-REGISTRATION, FEB. 27
Kindergarten registration for the 2020-21 school year begins March 4 at all Clovis Unified elementary schools, and parents may pre-register their child on any mobile device starting Feb. 27.

The online process will allow parents to fill out their child’s registration form and make an appointment to drop off the enrollment documents to their resident school. Parents unable to utilize the online process may go directly to their school site during regular hours beginning March 4 and will be helped through the online process.

At the time of registration, parents will need to provide a birth certificate or other birth record; proof of residency; and written evidence of up-to-date immunizations. To be eligible to register for kindergarten, a child must be 5 on or before Sept. 1.

Registration for new students entering grades 1-12 begins March 11.

For complete details or to access the online pre-registration, visit cusd.com.

SPOTLIGHT ON CLOVIS UNIFIED'S PEER COUNSELING PROGRAM
The George Lucas Educational Foundation highlighted Clovis Unified's peer counseling program in a just released "Edutopia-What Works in Schools" feature documentary.

"We're not psychologists. We're not telling people what to do. We're just simply being there to listen to [students] and let them know their voice will be heard," says Clovis East High health teacher Derrick Davis in describing the program and its impacts

Peer counselors are trained through an elective class that is offered at all secondary schools in the district. The classes teach students by engaging them in role playing scenarios, helping them identify how and when to make referrals for mental health services, and more. Students can self-refer or be referred by a teacher or a friend for a session during the school day.

Students are overcoming life's challenges one conversation at a time.

#BetterTogether #InspiringExcellence

TK HELPS HAWKINS THE CAT
Temperance-Kutner Elementary students spotted a familiar stray cat that kindergartners had nicknamed Hawkins atop of the baseball fence this week at school.

The cat stayed on the precarious perch for a couple of days, and students grew concerned. They wanted to make sure he (or she?) got down safe!

What to do?

Call the Fresno Fire Department who came to Hawkins’ aid. But as firefighters climbed a ladder to the top of the approximately 30-foot tall fence, the kitty decided to scale down the other side.

Much to everyone’s relief, Hawkins was able to get down safely!

Hundreds of students from Clovis Unified's high schools attended the Transition Leadership Conference this week. Also at the event, Gateway High teacher and transition counselor Randi Steele was presented with the Prandini Legacy Award for her impact on students.
Congratulations!
#BetterTogether #InspiringExcellence

LIBERTY ELEMENTARY A NATIONAL BLUE RIBBON SCHOOL!

The Skyhawks at Liberty Elementary School in Clovis Unified are celebrating after learning this week that the U.S. Department of Education selected their school as one of only 30 California schools named to the 2019 Blue Ribbon Schools list and the only school in Fresno County!

The northeast Fresno school, that serves close to 600 students, was honored with the Exemplary High Performing School award.

Recognition as a Blue Ribbon School is based on a school’s overall academic performance or progress in closing achievement gaps among student subgroups.

“We recognize and honor your important work in preparing students for successful careers and meaningful lives” said U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos in a video message to the honorees. “As a National Blue Ribbon School, your school demonstrates what is possible when committed educators hold all students and staff to high standards and create vibrant, innovative cultures of teaching and learning.”

#InspiringExcellence

RED MEANS STOP!
Local area law enforcement agencies and school districts are joining together to remind drivers they are required to stop when a school bus has its red lights flashing or stop sign extended. This indicates students are getting on or off a bus.

Red means stop. It's the law, and the right thing to do.

Schools will be back in session soon and more buses will be on the roads. (Clovis Unified starts Aug. 19.) Keep our children, bus drivers and motorists safe.

Both directions of traffic are required to stop when a bus has its red lights flashing. Failure to do so can result in fines of up to $1,000 and could mean loss of driving privileges for one year.

Don't pay the price in a fine or a life. Red means stop.

#RedMeansStop
#SafeSchoolYear

CHARGE FORWARD!
Clovis Unified school leadership, administrators and business support staff attended "Charge" today in preparation of the new school year.

Long ago, founding Superintendent Dr. Floyd "Doc" Buchanan said that in Clovis Unified, when we prepare for a new school year, we don't go on a retreat, rather we "charge" forward with unified plans, strategies and support.

Enthusiasm was high as Superintendent Dr. Eimear O'Farrell addressed more than 700 attendees in the Performing Arts Center.

"This is a group of people who is passionate about one thing -- and that is making sure that 43,000 students are successful every day."

Breakout sessions were held later in the day and are also planned for Tuesday as school site leadership continues the collaborative preparations for the 2019-20 year.

Clovis Unified's entire employee group of nearly 6,500 will meet for a back-to-school style rally and kickoff next week at the Save Mart Center.

We are excited to soon have our students back on campuses!

Picnics, fireworks and family gatherings are in order for today as the Declaration of Independence -- signed July 4, 1776 -- is celebrated across the USA.

From a letter written by John Adams to his wife, Abigail, regarding the Continental Congress' decision approving a resolution of independence and the Declaration of Independence explaining that decision: "...[This day] will be the most memorable epoch in the history of America. ...It ought to be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports ... from one end of this continent to the other, from this time forward forever more."

Have a happy and safe Fourth of July with family and friends!

This week hundreds of students in Clovis Unified's Summer Campus Club heard from award-winning poet L.Kobie Wiz Wilkerson. During his highly interactive sessions at CUSD school sites, students learned about and wrote poems. They were then invited to return in the evening with their parents to recite their poetry at "Poetry Jam."

“L. Kobie Da Wiz,” as he is known, is an international award-winning author, poet, speaker, presenter, storyteller, edutainer and master teacher. He uses music and literacy to “motivate and educate.” Whether he is conducting a professional development for teachers or working with groups of students, his goal is to provide his participants with the tools and skills they need to help them be the best version they can be.
